Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing with U-Net (GGSL-UNet). I. Extracting 2-Dimensional Information from Multi-Band Images in Ground and Space Observations

Fucheng Zhong School of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, Zhuhai Campus, 2 Daxue Road, Xiangzhou District, Zhuhai, 519082, P. R. China Ruibiao Luo Purple Mountain Observatory, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210023, P. R. China Nicola R. Napolitano Department of Physics E. Pancini, University Federico II, Via Cinthia 21, I-80126, Naples, Italy INAF â€“ Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy Crescenzo Tortora INAF â€“ Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy Rui Li Institude for Astrophysics, School of Physics, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, 450001, China Xincheng Zhu Department of Astronomy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Valerio Busillo Department of Physics E. Pancini, University Federico II, Via Cinthia 21, I-80126, Naples, Italy INAF â€“ Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, I-80131 Napoli, Italy L. V. E. Abstract

We present a novel deep learning method to separately extract the two-dimensional flux information of the foreground galaxy (deflector) and background system (source) of Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing events using U-Net (GGSL-Unet for short). In particular, the segmentation of the source image is found to enhance the performance of the lens modeling, especially for ground-based images. By combining mock lens foreground+background components with real sky survey noise to train the GGSL-Unet, we show it can correctly model the input image noise and extract the lens signal. However, the most important result of this work is that the GGSL-UNet can accurately reconstruct real ground-based lensing systems from the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) in one second. We also test the GGSL-UNet on space-based (HST) lenses from BELLS GALLERY, and obtain comparable accuracy of standard lens modeling tools. Finally, we calculate the magnitudes from the reconstructed deflector and source images and use this to derive photometric redshifts (photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z), with the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z of the deflector well consistent with spectroscopic ones. This first work, demonstrates the great potential of the generative network for lens finding, image denoising, source segmentation, and decomposing and modeling of strong lensing systems. For the upcoming ground- and space-based surveys, the GGSL-UNet can provide high-quality images as well as geometry and redshift information for precise lens modeling, in combination with classical MCMC modeling for best accuracy in the galaxy-galaxy strong lensing analysis.

galaxy-galaxy lens â€” photometric â€” deep learning â€” image reconstruction.

1 Introduction

Galaxy-galaxy lensing (GGL) has become an indispensable tool for studying the evolution of the universe, the nature of dark matter, and the structure and properties of galaxies (Treu, 2010; Hoekstra etÂ al., 2013).

Gravitational lensing is a phenomenon involving foreground galaxies (named lenses or deflectors) and background far-away systems (sources), where the gravitational field of the former total mass component distorts images of these latter systems. Depending on the mass of the deflector and the alignment of the source and the foreground galaxy, the GGL can be either â€œweakâ€ or â€œstrong.â€ In the â€œstrongâ€ version of this phenomenon, the lensed image of the sources can exhibit different symmetries depending on the relative positions of the background and foreground galaxies along the line of sight and the intrinsic shape of the source itself: a double or quadruply image or even an â€œEinstein crossâ€ (in case the four images form a perfect cross) in case the source is a compact system (e.g., a quasar, a galactic nucleus or even a supernova), a closed ring (aka â€œEinstein ringâ€) for a perfect alignment, or a semi-arc (Schneider etÂ al., 1992; Wambsganss, 1998) for a certain degree of alignment, in case of a more extended source (e.g., a galaxy). For larger misaligned, the GGL becomes â€œweak,â€ producing small deformations of the background sources, of the order of the thousandths of time of the original ellipticity, over large areas around the lens.

The â€œweakâ€ GGL provides a method for estimating the excess surface density and the halo profile with its statistics (e.g., Clampitt etÂ al. 2017; Luo etÂ al. 2018; Luo etÂ al. 2022; Dvornik etÂ al. 2023; Chaurasiya etÂ al. 2024), helping reconstruct the cluster mass distribution (Bartelmann & Schneider, 2001; BradaÄ etÂ al., 2005), and constraining the cosmological parameters (Cacciato etÂ al., 2009). The â€œstronglyâ€ lensed and magnified background galaxies, instead, offer a direct way to constraint the Hubble constant through the time delay of source variability (Refsdal, 1964; Koopmans etÂ al., 2003) and investigate very high redshift galaxies during the reionization epoch of the universe (e.g., Coe etÂ al. 2013; Atek etÂ al. 2015; Kawamata etÂ al. 2016; Coe etÂ al. 2019; Windhorst etÂ al. 2023). By incorporating the assumption of dark matter particle interactions on small scales, â€œstrongâ€ GGL can also provide an additional method for constraining different dark matter models (e.g., Gilman etÂ al. 2020, 2021, 2023). Obviously, the lensing phenomenon helps to map the fine details of the mass distribution of the foreground galaxy, such as dark matter substructures (e.g., Vegetti & Koopmans 2009a; Vegetti etÂ al. 2010, 2014), naturally providing strong constraints on its total mass, and dark matter fraction (Koopmans etÂ al., 2006; Gavazzi etÂ al., 2007; Vegetti & Koopmans, 2009b; Auger etÂ al., 2010; Treu, 2010; Tortora etÂ al., 2010; Saha etÂ al., 2024a).

Focusing on the strong lensing, with the advent of the III-Stage sky surveys (e.g., the Kilo Degree Survey, KiDS, de Jong etÂ al. 2013; the DeCAM Legacy Survey, DeCALs, Flaugher etÂ al. 2015; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration etÂ al. 2016; the Hyper Suprime Camera Survey, HSC, Aihara etÂ al. 2018) and the upcoming IV-Stage Surveys (e.g., Euclid Laureijs etÂ al. 2011; Vera Rubin Legacy Survey in Space and Time, LSST, IveziÄ‡ 2019); the China Space Station Telescope Survey, CSST, Zhan 2011), it has become mandatory to seek for the highest completeness in the lensing search to increase the number of lens targets and achieve statistical significance in scientific analysis, many automated strong lens detection tools have been developed (e.g., Bolton etÂ al. 2006; Sonnenfeld etÂ al. 2013; Gavazzi etÂ al. 2014; Petrillo etÂ al. 2017; Pourrahmani etÂ al. 2018; Petrillo etÂ al. 2019a, b; Li etÂ al. 2020, 2021; Thuruthipilly etÂ al. 2022; Nagam etÂ al. 2023; Thuruthipilly 2024), including both classical methods and deep-learning-based approaches. Thousands of lens candidates have been found, though a small fraction of them have been modeled. Modeling lenses often require images with a high enough Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), such as those from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) in the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS, Bolton etÂ al. 2006, 2008; Shu etÂ al. 2015, 2017) or the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS) for the GALaxy-LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± EmitteR sYstems (BELLS GALLERY, Shu etÂ al. 2016), as well as those from the HSC, such as the Survey of Gravitationally-Lensed Objects in HSC Imaging (SuGOHI, Sonnenfeld etÂ al. 2019). However, this process can be time-consuming and often requires empirical initial parameters. Furthermore, it is prone to degeneracies between the parameters of the foreground and background galaxy light, which can bias the mass inference. With the rapid development of generative neural networks, these networks can reconstruct images from given inputs, providing us with a novel way to denoise and model lensing objects. For instance, if we can model the different lens components with high accuracy, one can use the background light only to increase the speed and accuracy of standard MCMC modeling. This will help us to estimate the morphology parameters of the arc (Gentile etÂ al., 2023), as well as the redshift and photometric parameters (Zitrin etÂ al., 2011; Pignataro etÂ al., 2021). To provide these different lens components for the subsequent modeling task, we use U-Net (Ronneberger etÂ al., 2015), a generative deep learning model, to reconstruct noise-reduced images of the foreground and background sources, respectively, from the lens image input.

Using U-Net, we can reduce model dependency in lens modeling, decrease the number of parameters required, model the lens quickly, and provide key information, such as magnitude and photometric redshift (photo-z), for lens modeling. Through the reconstructed image, we can calculate and compare the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of different components transparently rather than directly obtaining lens parameters via a supervised deep learning model, which often appears as an unknown â€œblack box.â€ By knowing the flux from different components, we can even trace the foreground total mass using the geometry of the source flux distribution and trace the stellar mass using the foreground flux.

To evaluate the effectiveness of the reconstructed images, Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be calculated in the subsequent analysis. To demonstrate that the model trained on simulation data can be applied to real data, dozens of real lens images, including lens candidates from KiDS with corresponding spectroscopy measurements and BELLS GALLERY lenses from HST with modeling (see Â§2.2), are used as test samples. We also compare the reconstructed results with those obtained using the previous method based on Markov-Chain-Monte-Carlo (MCMC).

The contents of this paper are as follows: Â§2 introduces the dataset, including both simulated and real data. Â§3 covers the basic concept and technical details of reconstruction using U-Net. Â§4 presents the training results, the reconstructions on mock and real lenses, and a comparison with previous methods. In Â§C, we provide an example of a downstream task: predicting photometric redshift using the reconstructed images as input. Finally, in Â§5, some discussions and conclusions are provided.

2 Data

The main aim of this work is to train a UNet to accurately separate the signal from the lens, from the source, and the noise of a strong GGL system. In this section, we discuss the best strategies we have decided to adopt to efficiently train our Galaxy-Galaxy Strong Lensing with U-Net (GGSL-UNet here after) tool and the data used for the networkâ€™s training and testing phases.

2.1 Real or mock training samples?

There are a few thousand strong GGL candidates cataloged by different observational programs, such as SLACS (mentioned above), Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S, Sonnenfeld etÂ al. 2013), HSC lens candidates (Sonnenfeld etÂ al., 2018; CaÃ±ameras etÂ al., 2021; Shu etÂ al., 2022), DES (Nord etÂ al., 2016; Diehl etÂ al., 2017; Jacobs etÂ al., 2019), DECALS (Huang etÂ al., 2020, 2021; Stein etÂ al., 2022; Storfer etÂ al., 2022), and KiDS (Petrillo etÂ al., 2019c; Li etÂ al., 2020, 2021). The latest and largest catalogs have been more and more based on deep-learning techniques based on photometric data (for instance, Petrillo etÂ al. 2017; Li etÂ al. 2020) or even spectroscopy data (see Li etÂ al. 2019, and GaSNet Zhong etÂ al. 2022). Despite the large amount of high-quality candidates collected, these are insufficient to be directly used as the training set for DL models as they are far fewer than the requirements for DL model training. More importantly, it is impossible to define robust enough model parameters for them to be used as â€œground truthâ€ for network training. The parameters of modeled lenses are derived from certain codes, which might introduce systematic biases inherent to the code rather than totally reflecting the ground truth. These biases could be learned and inherited by the network trained on such data.

Using simulated lenses as training data is one way to solve this problem. Combining mock foreground and background sources with real sky survey image noise cutouts can produce data with realistic noise. By designing the network to fit the mock and the real noise components, one can expect to reconstruct the different components of both mock and real lenses. The critical point is that if the network can fit the real noise component very well, even when a mock or not fully realistic component is used in the training data, we can expect the rest of the components to be the signal we want after noise fitting. We can produce the lens images within the specified observation conditions and cover as many major physical situations as possible. In the next subsection, we introduce the main observation datasets that used in this paper.

2.2 Observation data and high-quality strong lens candidates

As anticipated, this paper focuses on two main datasets: KiDS and BELLS GALLERY. For this latter sample, we have specifically used the ones performed within the BELLS GALLERY sample as reference model performance. The main reason to choose KiDS is that this dataset provides some of the best image quality data (FWHMâˆ¼0.7â€²â€²similar-toabsentsuperscript0.7â€²â€²\sim 0.7^{\prime\prime}âˆ¼ 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in râˆ’limit-fromğ‘Ÿr-italic_r -band, see also below) currently available from ground observations and very similar pixel-scale to the one expected for the upcoming LSST observation. As such, we can use this dataset to prepare for the early LSST data strong lensing analyses. As we have discussed earlier, ground-based strong lensing systems are particularly challenging due to the higher mixing among the contribution of the light coming from the lens and the background light that introduces further degeneracies on top of the usual strong lensing model alone (Saha etÂ al., 2024b). HST observations, on the other hand, due to their extraordinary image quality (typical FWHMâˆ¼0.1â€²â€²similar-toabsentsuperscript0.1â€²â€²\sim 0.1^{\prime\prime}âˆ¼ 0.1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), provide a unique opportunity to fully validate our method, pushing it to the most extreme accuracy needed to optimize the image reconstruction of the lensing system and leave no residuals above the very low background of space observations. Below, we summarize the data used and their parent observations.

2.2.1 KiDS data

The Kilo-Degree Survey (KiDS, de Jong etÂ al. 2013) has been carried out using the OmegaCAM (Kuijken, 2011) mounted at the VLT Survey Telescope (VST; Capaccioli & Schipani 2011). It has covered an area of 1350 deg2superscriptdeg2\rm deg^{2}roman_deg start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the equatorial and southern sky in four (uâ¢gâ¢râ¢iğ‘¢ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ugriitalic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i) optical bands (see Wright et al. 2025 for a summary of the final data release observations). The optical observations from KiDS have been fully replicated within the VIKING project using the VIRCAM at the VISTA telescope (Edge etÂ al., 2013) in the near-infrared (NIR) bands (Zâ¢Yâ¢Jâ¢Hâ¢KSğ‘ğ‘Œğ½ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ‘†ZYJHK_{S}italic_Z italic_Y italic_J italic_H italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). To simulate lens images for ground-based telescopes such as KiDS, we needed to reproduce low SNR conditions and a noisy background realistically. To do that (see also Â§2.3), the noise component is directly taken from KiDS survey images by randomly selecting noise â€œcutoutsâ€ centers in the KiDS footprint. In particular, we have selected 100â€‰000 of these cutouts by checking that there were no pathological situations111This has been done by checking the statistics of the mean and rms values of the pixel counts in the cutouts. (e.g., stellar spikes, bright objects), but yet allowing for the presence of â€œcompanion sourcesâ€ rather than using fully â€œemptyâ€ areas to consider the presence or random source in the field of view in training (see also Â§2.3 and last columns in Fig. 1).

As a test sample, on the other hand, to be used after the GGSL-UNet has been trained to check the performance for application to real data, we will use the high-quality candidates of real strong gravitational lenses from the catalogs of (Petrillo etÂ al., 2017, 2019a, 2019b) 222https://www.astro.rug.nl/lensesinkids/full_left.html and Li etÂ al. (2020) derived from Fourth KiDS Data Release (DR4; Kuijken etÂ al. 2019). To select strong lens samples from KiDS, we follow two basic criteria. First, we keep the samples with the obvious structures of strong lensing cases, such as arcs or multiple images around the lens. Second, we select the cases matched with spectroscopic survey catalogs, such as SDSS (Bolton etÂ al., 2012; Smee etÂ al., 2013; Dawson etÂ al., 2016), GAMA (Hill etÂ al., 2011; Driver etÂ al., 2011), and MUSE (Napolitano etÂ al., 2020), which can provide precise spectroscopic redshifts (spec-z) for foreground galaxies. We finally identified 50 high-quality KiDS strong lens candidates, with their basic information shown in Table 1. This Table provides the ğµğ‘ƒğ‘ğµğ‘ƒğ‘\it BPZitalic_BPZ (BenÃ­tez, 2000, 2011) photometric redshift estimates based on 9-band (uâ¢gâ¢râ¢iâ¢Zâ¢Yâ¢Jâ¢Hâ¢KSğ‘¢ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘Œğ½ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ‘†ugriZYJHK_{S}italic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i italic_Z italic_Y italic_J italic_H italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) photometric data from KiDS+VIKING, derived using the Gaussian Aperture and Photometry (GAaP; Kuijken 2008) flux method. Here, we focus on the decoupling and photo-z estimation of foreground galaxies and arcs from background sources in this paper.

2.2.2 HST data

As space-based observations, we use the lenses from the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS) for the GALaxy-LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± EmitteR sYstems (BELLS GALLERY, Shu etÂ al. 2016). This is chosen because it provides complete foreground and background modeling, which can be used to assess the performance of our GGSL-UNet. It consists of 17 rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-band lens systems whose images will be used as test samples to compare with the GGSL-UNet reconstructed images. The lenses in this sample have been identified using a spectroscopic method that detects the presence of anomalous emission lines from higher redshift galaxies superimposed on the spectra of luminous red galaxies (LRGs). The massive galaxies typically targeted by BOSS spectroscopy are at redshifts zâˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼0.5-0.8. The emission lines, primarily [OII] Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»3727, HÎ²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², and [OIII] Î»â¢Î»ğœ†ğœ†\lambda\lambdaitalic_Î» italic_Î»4959,5007, originate from star-forming regions of background galaxies at higher redshifts (zâˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼1-1.5) that are gravitationally lensed by the foreground LRGs. Regarding the modeling approach, we can benefit from the results of Shu etÂ al. 2016 that have used the modeling tool lâ¢fâ¢iâ¢tgâ¢uâ¢iğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘”ğ‘¢ğ‘–lfit_{gui}italic_l italic_f italic_i italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g italic_u italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a graphical user interface (GUI) to smoothly analyze the BELLS GALLERY lenses using HST F606W-band images with manual feature masks. The tool simultaneously fits the lens light (elliptical SÃ©rsic profiles), the mass parameters (SIE with external shear), and source light (SÃ©rsic or pixelated profiles) to the HST imaging data. A B-spline fitting is also applied to refine the background subtraction and source representation. Finally, an MCMC optimization has been applied to constrain the lens and source positions, flux ratios, and Einstein radii by minimizing the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT between the ray tracing model and the pixel data of the HST images. This approach balances efficiency with flexibility, yielding lens models and source reconstructions.

This is prone to degeneracies among the different contributions that are harder to break for large spatial overlaps between the two components. This is the typical situation we have for ground-based observations with poorer seeing. We have tried to mitigate this situation in constructing our tool, as we will detail in Â§3. Each band has corresponding randomly chosen magnitudes or slopes (represented by the Greek letters). Here, Î±=Î±(band,1,1)ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼band11\alpha=\alpha_{\rm(band,1,1)}italic_Î± = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_band , 1 , 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the other Greek letters are also 4-dimensional vectors sampled from a uniform distribution. The range of the uniform distribution is shown in Table 2. Note that the flat priors in these training parameters of Table correspond to a flat prior to the colors, which we have deliberately chosen because we wanted the network to reconstruct the lens based on its geometry rather than use the color information. This will ensure no color biases are introduced in the reconstruction of different bands.

The foreground and background images in four different bands share the same ellipticity and effective radius. In real cases, the effective radius or SÃ©rsic index might vary across different bands, which we approximate by tuning parameters such as Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. The foreground models in different bands differ in magnitude and slope (Î±,Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha,\gammaitalic_Î± , italic_Î³). Because the background source is a smaller, more compact object with a smaller effective radius, we did not consider its slope change for simplicity compared to the foreground. Therefore, the difference between the background models in different bands is only in magnitude (Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\betaitalic_Î± , italic_Î²) and does not involve any slope (Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³) tuning for simplicity. We remind you that the noise is randomly sampled from the reference dataset (KiDS or HST in our case) with no source in the center but with no restriction on the presence of other sources off-center. This also allows us to include possible â€œcompanionâ€ or â€œcontaminantâ€ sources in the training sample, reproducing realistic observational conditions that might or might not involve overlapping sources blended within the signal from the strong lensing components. The foreground and background images are normalized by their maximum values, while the noise is normalized by its median value. Using these augmentations has two advantages. First, it can reduce the volume of training data. Second, the training data can explore a more expansive parameter space; the amplitude and slope parameters can tune the color information while the geometric information remains unchanged.

To mock the foreground deflector and background sources, we have used a single SÃ©rsic profile (Ciotti & Bertin, 1999; MacArthur etÂ al., 2003). Although this is not the most realistic model we can use to reproduce more complex multicomponent systems, this has been shown to capture most of the galaxy properties and provide a good approximation to produce training samples for deep learning tools that have successfully applied to real galaxies (see, e.g., the measurement of structural parameters, Li etÂ al. 2022). To generalize the typical strong lensing configurations for the foreground system, we have also considered a â€œblendingâ€ situation where twenty percent of the deflector is constituted by a pair of galaxies with two different SÃ©rsic models and centers slight offset within one Î¸Esubscriptğœƒğ¸\theta_{E}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, to train the U-Net to consider the cases of false detections, we randomly set 5% of the training set made of Fb=0subscriptğ¹ğ‘0F_{b}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 (i.e., no-background signal) to help the U-Net to recognize cases without true galaxy background signal.

The parameters for the foreground and the background SÃ©rsic profiles are shown in Table 2. We used flat distributions for all parameters to avoid an unbalanced training sample and a realistic range of intrinsic parameters, as suggested from the real data (see, e.g., the BELL GALLERY, Shu etÂ al. 2016). As a first proof-of-concept test, in this paper, we cover a reasonable volume of the physical parameter space of the lensing systems, despite this might not fully consider all possible parameters, including extreme cases (for example, we are excluding very flat foreground systems with qâˆ¼0.2âˆ’0.3similar-toğ‘0.20.3q\sim 0.2-0.3italic_q âˆ¼ 0.2 - 0.3). This option makes the network training more efficient, fast, and easier to converge while improving performance within the primary parameter space. Although the parameter space has been chosen to optimize the model training, the testing step in the following section shows that the GGSL-Unet still performs excellently in most mock/real lens test cases, as quantified by the chi-squares diagnostic. The projected potential of the background galaxy is calculated according to a singular isothermal ellipsoid profile (SIE, Kormann etÂ al. 1994), which shares the same geometry parameters, like center, Pâ¢Ağ‘ƒğ´PAitalic_P italic_A, and qğ‘qitalic_q, as the foreground SÃ©rsic model. Some examples of mock KiDS-like and HST-like mock strong lensing configurations, generated under different augmentation parameters, are shown in Fig.Â 1. They include the total lensing system images (first column on the left), the foreground galaxy images (second column), the background images (third column), and noise images (fourth column). The lensing system images are the input of our network, and the foreground, background, and noise images are the ones we want to reconstruct with the GGSL-UNet. Despite the simplified lens model used in our training data, we will show that the network can already reconstruct the lensing systemâ€™s different components rather accurately, not only if applied to mock lens images but also to real strong lensing events.

3 Method

We use U-Net to extract the different components of lens images. The U-Net model is a type of generative model consisting of two main branches: down-sampling and up-sampling blocks with shortcuts at the same level. The down-sampling and up-sampling blocks mainly comprise ResNet structure units (He etÂ al., 2015) and transformer structure units (Vaswani etÂ al., 2017). The down-sampling reduces the dimension of features, while the up-sampling increases them. In our case, this means reducing the imageâ€™s last two dimensions (see Eq. 5). For instance, the first down-sampling block in Table 3 reduces the input image size from 4Ã—64Ã—64464644\times 64\times 644 Ã— 64 Ã— 64 to 32Ã—32Ã—3232323232\times 32\times 3232 Ã— 32 Ã— 32). We use the Python module diffusers 444https://pypi.org/project/diffusers/ (von Platen etÂ al., 2022) to quickly build a U-Net model, in which the blocks and the channels used are shown in Table 3.

U-Net has been widely applied in image segmentation (Siddique etÂ al., 2020), producing output images of the same size as the input and effectively modeling noise through skip connections in its architecture. Recently, U-Net has also been applied to improve the performance of strong gravitational lens searching (N etÂ al., 2024) and modeling (Ostdiek etÂ al., 2022; Reddy etÂ al., 2024). Besides image segmentation, it can also be integrated into a framework to enhance the quality and accuracy of generated scientific images.

The input to the U-Net is preprocessed to have a uniform range of flux. The flux Fxsubscriptğ¹ğ‘¥F_{x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is normalized by the maximum flux within the input imageâ€™s 1Ã—1â¢aâ¢râ¢câ¢sâ¢eâ¢c11arcsec1\times 1\rm arcsec1 Ã— 1 roman_a roman_r roman_c roman_s roman_e roman_c center area as follows:

Nâ¢oâ¢râ¢mâ¢(Fx)=Fx/maxâ¢(Fiâ¢(1â€²â€²Ã—1â€²â€²)).ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptğ¹ğ‘¥subscriptğ¹ğ‘¥maxsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscript1â€²â€²superscript1â€²â€²\displaystyle Norm(F_{x})=F_{x}/{\rm max}(F_{i}(1^{\prime\prime}\times 1^{% \prime\prime})).italic_N italic_o italic_r italic_m ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_max ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) . (10)

To avoid fake outputs or â€œhallucinationsâ€ (Ji etÂ al., 2023), which is important for scientific applications, we will use some â€˜masksâ€™ generated by U-Net. By multiplying the masks with the input images, we aim to produce realistic output images. Our adopted procedure is shown in Fig. 3. Here, the mask generated by the U-Net represents the probability of different components in each pixel. These probabilities are positive, by definition, and they sum up to 1 by normalization. With these definitions, the flux of each component of the total signal per pixel (i.e., foreground, background, and noise), as well as the normalization of the masks, is defined as:

As a loss function to fit the output to the different components of the lens, we use the L1 function defined as:

where F^xsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘¥\hat{F}_{x}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the predicted flux value, and Fxsubscriptğ¹ğ‘¥F_{x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the true value of different components. The sum of the mean absolute error is used because we expect to have the same back-propagation gradients for different components. We trained the network in the PyTorch 555https://pytorch.org framework.

The training loop of the network is described in the Algorithm 1 inset. Here, the training sets consist of two kinds of data. First, the theoretical mock data, Xm=(If,Ib)âˆ¼Uâ¢(a,b)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘šsubscriptğ¼ğ‘“subscriptğ¼ğ‘similar-toğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘X_{m}=(I_{f},I_{b})\sim U(a,b)italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¼ italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ), are obtained by sampling their parameters from the uniform distribution listed for the foreground, background, and lens components in Table 2. Second, the real noise data, Xr=Inâˆ¼Sâ¢uâ¢râ¢vâ¢eâ¢ysubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ¼ğ‘›similar-toğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘¦X_{r}=I_{n}\sim Surveyitalic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_S italic_u italic_r italic_v italic_e italic_y, are randomly picked from observed images. Following the Algorithm 1 inset, for the mock data, we have sampled the parameters from the distribution Uâ¢(a,b)ğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘U(a,b)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ) (last three parts of Table 2), generated Ifsubscriptğ¼ğ‘“I_{f}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ibsubscriptğ¼ğ‘I_{b}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and then sampled Insubscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{n}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the survey images. The model is trained in batches, where the augmentation parameters are sampled from Uâ¢(a,b)ğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘U(a,b)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_b ) (the first part of Table 2) to obtain Ff,Fb,Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘“subscriptğ¹ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{f},F_{b},F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the training targets. As discussed in Â§2.3, we have used online augmentation. This means the augmented training samples are constructed â€œon the flyâ€ during training. For instance, this can include image rotating or zooming. In this case, we change the magnitude, slope, and color during training.

A total of 100â€‰000 mock images are generated and separated into 90%percent9090\%90 % for training and 10%percent1010\%10 % for validation. Another new identical mock of 1,000 images will serve as a test set to demonstrate the model performed on mock data. Fifty epochs were executed for the training. During this phase, the loss function in Eq. 13 is monitored to assess the model convergence. The training and validation losses are plotted in Fig. 4, where we can see that, after training, the loss converged to a stable value, and the checkpoints with minimal validation loss were saved.

4 Evaluation and results

In this section, we discuss the performance of the GGSL-UNet on both mock and real data. Besides evaluating the accuracy in the segmentation of the different components of the lensing systems, we will discuss how to use the ability of the GGSL-UNet to efficiently pick any strong lensing feature and the background contribution (including nearby projected random galaxies) to classify the images as lensing or non-lensing systems. We also assess the accuracy in the total flux reconstruction of the different components to produce catalogs of multi-band total magnitudes of the foreground and background systems for spectral energy distribution analyses (e.g., photometric redshifts or stellar populations).

4.1 GGSL-UNet as foreground/background/noise segmentation tool

For a lens image, one should expect Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be smaller than Ï‡12superscriptsubscriptğœ’12\chi_{1}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the former is calculated after the background is also fitted, rather than only the foreground. This is seen in Fig. 5.

Indeed, in the figure, we can see that the U-Net can recover the geometry and color information of the foreground and background components, which usually produces Ï‡22<2subscriptsuperscriptğœ’222\chi^{2}_{2}<2italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 2. In these cases, by visually comparing the residual images, Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F^nsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘›\hat{F}_{n}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can see that the U-Net can reproduce the same level of noise as in the original data from the corresponding survey, demonstrating that we can extract information by properly modeling the real noise. Strikingly, the network can reconstruct very complex cases as pair-system lenses with a similar level of accuracy (see bottom row of Fig. 5, but see also Appendix A). On the other hand, we always have Ï‡12>Ï‡22subscriptsuperscriptğœ’21subscriptsuperscriptğœ’22\chi^{2}_{1}>\chi^{2}_{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT due to the presence of the background signal in the Fiâˆ’F^fsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscript^ğ¹ğ‘“F_{i}-\hat{F}_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq. 14. We will discuss the GGSL-UNet as a tool for lens finding in Â§4.2.

The reconstructed images and residuals are compared in Appendix B for some systems for a visual comparison. This result is likely due to the ability of the U-Net to separate the background signal from the noise without being dominated by the model errors and degeneracies. This opens two very promising perspectives: 1) that the generative models, or similar deep learning networks, can be used to more efficiently isolate the background signal for more accurate modeling using standard techniques, or 2) that one can use the GGSL-UNet itself to infer the main lens parameters.

4.3 GGSL-UNet as photometry reconstruction tool

In image segmentation or de-noising, an exquisite Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not guarantee that the signal segmentation (as in Eq. 1) is degeneracy-free. Since one of the great advantages of our method is the possibility to integrate the signal associated with every component to derive total fluxes, we need to demonstrate that the U-Net output images can preserve the flux information in every band and, consequently, the color information in multi-band catalogs. This is of paramount importance for science applications. One classic example is the derivation of the photometric redshifts, where the multi-band photometry and colors are fitted to theoretical or observational templates of galaxies to derive the redshift (see, e.g., ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE, Arnouts etÂ al. 1999; Ilbert etÂ al. 2006). We will show such an application to the KiDS photometry derived with GGSL-UNet in Appendix C. Another example is using the multi-band photometric information of the source and the deflector to derive stellar population parameters (see, e.g., Li etÂ al. 2023). Hence, we need to investigate the photometry accuracy that one can derive from the flux breakdown in all image pixels as described in Â§3. Obviously, this can only be done for the mock samples for which the â€˜ground truthâ€™ magnitudes are known. We remark here that, as we use real noise background cutouts, we expect these, combined with the lensed source signal, to dominate the photometric errors, thus providing a realistic assessment of the overall precision of the reconstructed magnitudes. Also, we concentrate only on the KiDS sample for two reasons: 1) it is the only dataset for which we have the color information (the BELL GALERY sample has only one band), and 2) it is the worst-case scenario as we have seen that, for HST, the reconstruction is always better so we can use the ground-based observation as an upper limit on the photometric accuracy reachable for the strong lensing reconstruction with GGSL-UNet. The magnitudes of the input and output mock images are then simply defined as666https://kids.strw.leidenuniv.nl/DR4/format.php:

mx=âˆ’2.5â¢log10â¢âˆ‘(x,y)=(0,0)(64,64)F^x,subscriptğ‘šğ‘¥2.5subscript10superscriptsubscriptxy006464subscript^ğ¹ğ‘¥\displaystyle m_{x}=-2.5\log_{10}\sum_{\rm(x,y)=(0,0)}^{(64,64)}\hat{F}_{x},italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 2.5 roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_x , roman_y ) = ( 0 , 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 64 , 64 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (17)

for every component x=f,b,nğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘›x=f,b,nitalic_x = italic_f , italic_b , italic_n as discussed in Â§3. Fig. 11 top panel shows the accuracy for the four band magnitudes of the foreground and background components of the KiDS mocks, using this definition, while the bottom panel shows the same results for the HST mocks. The x-axis represents the magnitudes for the mock (precisely Ffsubscriptğ¹ğ‘“F_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Fbsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{b}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the full or empty symbols, respectively), while the y-axis represents the difference between the output and input magnitudes for F^fsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘“\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or F^bsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (symbols as above). In the same figure, we show the distributions of the input-output magnitudes that allow us to highlight the presence of systematics. From this figure, we can derive two main features.

First, looking at the input-output distributions, for KiDS, there are almost no systematics for the foreground magnitudes (median Mfâˆ¼0.03similar-tosubscriptğ‘€ğ‘“0.03M_{f}\sim 0.03italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ 0.03 and scatter Ïƒfâˆ¼0.11similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘“0.11\sigma_{f}\sim 0.11italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ 0.11 across the different bands, as in the inset), although we also observe a tail toward the positive deviation (overestimate). Such an overestimate is more evident for the background magnitudes: here, the offset has a median Mbâˆ¼0.08similar-tosubscriptğ‘€ğ‘0.08M_{b}\sim 0.08italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ 0.08 and scatter Ïƒbâˆ¼0.35similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘0.35\sigma_{b}\sim 0.35italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ 0.35. For HST, there is no bias for both foreground and background magnitudes (M<0.003ğ‘€0.003M<0.003italic_M < 0.003, i.e., smaller than typical photometric calibration errors) with a scatter that is âˆ¼80%similar-toabsentpercent80\sim 80\%âˆ¼ 80 % smaller than the corresponding KiDS rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-band for the background magnitude, while it is only half of the precision of KiDS foreground photometry.

Second, looking at the input-output vs. input magnitude plot, for KiDS, the foreground galaxies have magnitudes that are recovered within 1Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ, especially for mag>21absent21>21> 21, and the median deviation is always contained within âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼0.05 mag in all bands (except for very bright sources at mag<19absent19<19< 19 that show a positive offset marginally consistent with zero within 1Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ). The background source magnitudes, instead, are systematically overestimated by âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼0.1 mag. At a very close look, one may also see a trend to increase the offset for the background magnitude and decrease the offset for the foreground magnitudes toward fainter magnitudes (see comment below). There are no trends for HST, and all magnitudes are very accurately recovered by the U-Net. This shows a superiority of the predictions in space observations vs. ground-based observation in general, which might come from the better image quality (see below).

In principle, one can foresee that the presence of these systematics for the background photometry can impact the quantities that are based on total fluxes (luminosities, stellar masses, etc.) as the fainter systems (typically higher redshifts or less magnified galaxies) would result fainter and less massive than they really are. As this trend with the magnitudes is similar in all bands, this does not seem to affect the colors. Hence, one can argue that these systematics would have less impact on the quantities based on colors (e.g., the photometric redshifts).

Besides registering these potential systematics, we should try to assess the origin of these offsets here to elaborate strategies for future improvements. In this respect, the fact that both foreground and background systems are overestimated, regardless of the intrinsic magnitude, means that there is some flux missing from the U-Net segmentation as in Eq. 1. While one can expect that this should be easy to predict in the high-SNR pixels, this might become difficult at the low-SNR, where the signal is overwhelmed by the noise. In these pixels, we can argue that the GGSL-Unet tends to overweight the noise and subtracts flux to either the background, foreground, or both. As a partial demonstration of that, we have tested if the offset is alleviated using sharper surface brightness profiles for both foreground and background, setting the nğ‘›nitalic_n-index to stay within [1-4] and limiting the q>0.4ğ‘0.4q>0.4italic_q > 0.4 to reduce the degeneracies among the parameters in the reconstruction. In this case, the offset for the foreground and the background systems reduced to 0.010.010.010.01 and 0.070.070.070.07 with a scatter of 0.1 and 0.2, respectively, hence suggesting a noticeable improvement. Currently, to keep the parameter space as wide as possible, we decided to live with these systematics for the KiDS reconstructed photometry, keeping in mind that they have to be related to the structure of the noise in KiDS. Indeed, this effect is not seen in the HST images (see bottom panel of Fig. 11). According to the discussion above, we can explain this with the fact that, first, for HST images, the SNR is much higher than in KiDS and, second, the PSF in HST is sharper, and then the quality is higher than in the KiDS observations, making even the smoother light profiles easier for the U-Net to detect and then reconstruct the related image.

5 Discussion and conclusion

In this paper, we have applied the generative network U-Net to reconstruct different components of galaxy-galaxy strong lensing images, namely the foreground (fğ‘“fitalic_f) deflector light, the deformed image of the background source (bğ‘bitalic_b), either arc-like or multiple-imaged, and the noise (nğ‘›nitalic_n), usually denoted as â€œsky background.â€ The tool for this Galaxy-Galaxy Strong lensing reconstruction using U-Net (GGSL-UNet for short) has been applied to high-quality strong lensing candidates from the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) and for a sample of HST-confirmed strong lensing events fully modeled within the BELLS GALLERY project.

The GGSL-UNetâ€™s main feature is the generation of masks that represent different â€œweightsâ€ for the contribution from the foreground, background, and noise to each pixelâ€™s flux. The network has been trained on realistic training samples that we have constructed by combining noise (i.e., sky background) samples from different real survey data with theoretical mock foreground and background models, assumed to follow SÃ©rsic profiles, which we have further improved by taking advantage of online augmentation. Using an appropriate L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT loss function to guide the U-Net in fitting different components â€”- especially the noise -â€” in the training data, we have optimized the performances of the U-Net in extracting the signals for the foreground and background systems. Despite the fact that the light densities from the fğ‘“fitalic_f/bğ‘bitalic_b components are rather idealized (single SÃ©rsic profile, no substructures, etc.), the U-Net could still learn how to accurately model the real noise, allowing the network to extract these signals correctly.

By modeling the multi-color band images of KiDS, we have demonstrated that a well-trained U-Net network can reproduce the foreground and background components for both mock and real data. The color and geometry information in the images are well retained in the reconstructed components. The U-Net performs well even in low SNR situations, with a Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (defined in Â§4.2) remaining within reasonable values. For cases with no strong lensing signatures, the U-Net could still model the foreground source very effectively, indicating that the generative network can also be used as a source extraction tool (see, e.g., SExtractor, Bertin & Arnouts 1996).

The GGSL-UNet used to reconstruct different components of the HST rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-band images differs from the one used for KiDS strong lenses, mainly for the noise component and the different PSF adopted to convolve the SÃ©rsic models of both the foreground (deflector) and the background (source) galaxies. We have compared the reconstructed components with the BELLS GALLERY models (see Appendix B) and found that the U-Net reconstruction shows an accuracy comparable to classical methods. Comparing the mean Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we demonstrate that GGSL-UNet has a better overall performance in reconstructing the total luminosity from the two strong lensing components, foreground+background, as shown in Fig. 10.

In addition to the segmentation of strong lensing events, we have also shown other possible applications of the network to other typical tasks to be performed in large imaging surveys like denoising images and extracting sources as illustrated in Fig. 8 and searching for lenses as shown in Fig. 9.

For Strong lensing, the GGSL-UNet has an extreme potential to be improved further. It can be applied to different kinds of sources by using different training samples in different survey data. For instance, we can model AGN as background sources, as well as implement more complex SÃ©rsic models or the Nuker model (Graham etÂ al., 2003) to improve the reconstruction power of the U-Net in space-based observations, or we can add more realistic contaminants in the training sample, such as spiral galaxies.

Even in the current basic version, the GGSL-UNet output is expected to represent a crucial step for strong lensing modeling if used in combination with standard MCMC or other deep learning tools such as LEMON (Gentile etÂ al., 2023) to determine the corresponding strong lensing parameters, which is considered a downstream task for sophisticated analysis in the current all-sky surveys where hundreds or thousands of these events are expected to be found.

With this paper, we have started by demonstrating the effectiveness of lens image decomposition and photometry reconstruction under different noise conditions (ground-based KIDS and space-based HST). For the upcoming data from ground-based surveys, such as LSST, Wide Field Survey Telescope (WFST, Wang etÂ al. 2023), and space-based surveys, such as Euclid (Laureijs etÂ al., 2011), Roman (Spergel etÂ al., 2015), and the China Space Station Telescope surveys, our tools will provide high-quality images for lens modeling and multi-band photometry reconstruction of both deflector and source.

Appendix A Anomaly cases

In Â§4, we have used the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT metrics to assess the quality of the GGSL-Unet reconstruction, and we have seen that despite the majority of cases showing a Ï‡22<2superscriptsubscriptğœ’222\chi_{2}^{2}<2italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 2, âˆ¼20%similar-toabsentpercent20\sim 20\%âˆ¼ 20 % of KiDS models and âˆ¼10%similar-toabsentpercent10\sim 10\%âˆ¼ 10 % of HST models showed a larger Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We stress here (as anticipated in Â§3) that, by construction, the Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT value can be strongly influenced by the structure of the â€œnoiseâ€ image, as strong substructures in its flux (Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which would be difficult to reconstruct by the U-Net, and then produce larger Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, high Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not generally mean bad reconstruction, as we will show below. On the other hand, there are situations where high Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values come from bad reconstructions. Here, we want to look into the different cases to check whether there are avenues for improvements or if there are pathological cases we need to live with.

We start by showing some of the mock objects with large Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT values in Fig. 12, where we can distinguish the following cases:

  1. 1.

    Pair of foreground galaxies. Despite the fact that the GGSL-Unet can generally model these cases (see Â§4.1), which are contemplated in the training sample, there are still cases where the reconstruction is not optimal. This is shown in rows 1 and 2 of Fig. 12, where we can see the GGSL-Unet can still fit the foreground properly but with a poorer Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Very bright â€œcompanionâ€ objects (e.g., bright stars). In Rows 3 and 4 of Fig. 12, the very bright objects located very close to or even overlapping with the lens strongly impact the Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, although both the foreground and the background images are nicely reconstructed.

  3. 3.

    Low SNR arcs. In Rows 5 and 6 of Fig. 12, the background signal level is low, and most of them are overwhelmed by noise, but U-Net can still reconstruct the geometry roughly.

The â€œfailedâ€ cases are instead shown in Fig. 13. Here, we can also distinguish different situations:

  1. 1.

    Corrupted images. In Rows 1 and 2 of Fig. 13, Fnsubscriptğ¹ğ‘›F_{n}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is randomly selected from the KiDS survey, and the edges of tiles or artificial signals make the image broken. Surprisingly, the reconstruction in Row 1 seems reasonably good (despite the large Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT due to the irregular â€œnoiseâ€ structure).

  2. 2.

    Crowded fields. In Rows 3 and 4 of 13, the weak background signal and the presence of external sources may cause the incorrect reconstruction of the background galaxy.

  3. 3.

    False positive candidates. In the last two rows of Fig 13, we show some no-lensing systems. Due to the absence of a background signal and heavy noise, some noise is misinterpreted as a background signal.

To summarise, anomalous Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT generally imply a bad reconstruction, but, as shown in this appendix, they might also indicate a complex â€œnoiseâ€ (i.e., sky background) structure. This latter case is generally true for ground-based observations, while the sharper image of space observations provides a smoother noise structure. As a strategy for practical application, one can foresee an inspection of the large Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cases (either using human eyeball checks or deep learning algorithm) to retain the cases with good Ffsubscriptğ¹ğ‘“F_{f}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Fbsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{b}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reconstructions.

Appendix B More lens reconstruction

We show 20 KiDS lens candidates in Fig. 14. The Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and residuals indicate that the foreground and background components generated by U-Net are well-modeled. Most lens candidates here have low SNR, and some have extra sources besides the foreground and background components. In some cases, the foreground and background sources are very close to each other, but the U-Net can still model them very well. One issue is that the U-Net might misinterpret the arm of a spiral galaxy as a background arc. We believe this can be resolved by introducing more relevant spiral foreground training samples to the network.

We also show the 8 BELLS GALLERY images (only rğ‘Ÿritalic_r-band) reconstructed by the U-Net in Fig. 15. Differently from the KiDS cases, here we can compare the GGSL-Unet reconstruction with the ray-tracing model by Shu etÂ al. (2016). Columns 2 and 4 in the figure represent models of standard classical ray-tracing methods. We include them here to compare the deep learning and traditional MCMC-based classical methods. By comparing the Ï‡22superscriptsubscriptğœ’22\chi_{2}^{2}italic_Ï‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can claim that the U-Net modeling achieves at least the same level of accuracy as the classical method, and in some cases, it performs even better.

Appendix C Downstream task: Photometric redshift

In Â§4, we have demonstrated that 1) the U-Net can effectively denoise and â€œdecoupleâ€ the foreground galaxy and background components from the input lens image; 2) the U-Net can also reconstruct the intrinsic photometry of the strong lensing components, although, for the ground-based observations, there are systematic offsets between estimated magnitudes and true values.

To illustrate a practical application of the GGSL-Unet output, we have estimated the photometric redshift as a downstream task. We calculate the magnitude of different bands from reconstructed fore/background images and obtain the photometric redshift for both components.

The aperture magnitude of the foreground and background sources are approximately calculated following Eq. 17. In Fig. 16, we plot the foreground and background magnitudes, mfsubscriptğ‘šğ‘“m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are calculated using the reconstructed optical band flux F^fsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘“\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and F^bsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, versus the KiDS catalog magnitude, MAG_GAaP in Table 1. Here, we have corrected mfsubscriptğ‘šğ‘“m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for extinction, as has already been done for the KiDS catalog magnitudes (MAG_GAaP, see Kuijken etÂ al. 2019). The mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘m_{b}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is much larger than mfsubscriptğ‘šğ‘“m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as expected, since most of the lens candidates in the dataset have lower flux compared to the foreground galaxy. Considering that the foreground flux is difficult to distinguish from the background and noise when the flux is low, we have additionally applied a correction for the foreground, using the flux inside the 95% flux contour of F^fsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘“\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One would expect mfsubscriptğ‘šğ‘“m_{f}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to approximate MAG_GAaP, but it is slightly larger in the uğ‘¢uitalic_u band. As MAG_GAaP is derived from galaxy shapes and position angles, the GAaP method may not be able to distinguish between the lens and arcs in low SNR images, such as those in the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band. Consequently, MAG_GAaP values for uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band images might include contributions from both the lens and the background galaxy. Because the flux F^fsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘“\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only includes the flux of the foreground, we calculate the total flux of the foreground, F^fsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘“\hat{F}_{f}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and background, F^bsubscript^ğ¹ğ‘\hat{F}_{b}over^ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The magnitude is then calculated using Eq 17, and the results are shown in Fig. 17. The figure shows that the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band matches better when considering both foreground and background flux, but the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band magnitudes are still slightly overestimated in this case. Nonetheless, it demonstrates that the background image contributes a significant portion of the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band flux. This is consistent with the physical scenario of the lens where the foreground galaxy is redder while the background is bluer.

From the figure, we can see that for the foreground, the gğ‘”gitalic_g, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, and iğ‘–iitalic_i magnitudes are well reproduced by the U-Net output. However, the deviation in the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band magnitude is considerably larger. This is because the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band flux is much smaller than the other redder bands, making the noise and background contribute much higher than in other bands, hence causing larger relative error.

Due to the large uncertainties in the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band magnitude, we predict the foreground redshift using the remaining bands, gğ‘”gitalic_g, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, and iğ‘–iitalic_i. We match the corresponding targets with the spectroscopic measurements and use the spectroscopic redshift as the ground truth. In Fig. 18, we demonstrate the foreground photometric redshift estimated by ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE versus the spectroscopic redshift. ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸ğ¿ğ‘’ğ‘ƒğ»ğ´ğ‘…ğ¸\it LePHAREitalic_LePHARE photo-zğ‘§zitalic_zhave been obtained using stellar templates from Bruzual & Charlot (2003) with a Chabrier (2003) initial mass function (IMF) and an exponentially decaying star formation history. The photometric redshift is calculated using magnitudes either provided by the KiDS catalog or derived from Eq. 17 using U-Net outputs. As mentioned for the foreground galaxy, we have estimated the photometric redshift using only the magnitudes of three bands (gâ¢râ¢iğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘–griitalic_g italic_r italic_i). However, for comparison, we have also estimated the photometric redshift using 9-band magnitudes, adding the near-infrared (NIR) magnitudes from Zâ¢Yâ¢Hâ¢Jâ¢Ksğ‘ğ‘Œğ»ğ½subscriptğ¾ğ‘ ZYHJK_{s}italic_Z italic_Y italic_H italic_J italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the KiDS/VIKING catalog (see again Kuijken etÂ al. 2019). The different photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z estimates of the foreground galaxy from the photometric combinations above are shown in Fig. 18. Here, we can clearly see that the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z based on optical band only is very poorly estimated (scatter Î´=0.14ğ›¿0.14\delta=0.14italic_Î´ = 0.14) as compared to the full 9-band photometry for which we have found a scatter Î´=0.05ğ›¿0.05\delta=0.05italic_Î´ = 0.05 and all estimates aligned along the 1-to-1 relation. However, we can see that the GGSL-Unet photometry also allowed us to obtain similar accuracy and precision (Î´=0.06ğ›¿0.06\delta=0.06italic_Î´ = 0.06) of the 9-band KiDS photometry, showing a substantial consistency for the foreground galaxy and the reliability of our photometry reconstruction in the optical bands, although we have assessed the presence of systematics of 0.03 mag (see Â§4.3).

To make the U-Net model fully multi-band (from optical to NIR) and possibly achieve higher accuracy in redshift estimation, we need to incorporate additional infrared bands into the U-Net training. This is one of the next steps of our project for upcoming papers.

This important implementation will be fundamental for accurate photo-z of the background sources. To derive the integrated photometry of the background galaxies in the optica+NIR, we also need the GGSL-Unet to perform in NIR images. Currently, we have tried to assess the accuracy of the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z based only on the U-Net optical photometry. This is shown in Fig. 19, where the background redshift estimated using four optical bands (uâ¢gâ¢râ¢iğ‘¢ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ugriitalic_u italic_g italic_r italic_i) is plotted against the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground as a sanity check. Here, we have also considered the uğ‘¢uitalic_u-band in the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z determination, despite the systematics discussed above, but not as severe for the background source as the foreground.

The figure shows that the majority of the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z of the background source is larger than the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground system, hence suggesting that this is compatible with a lensing system. We want to stress that if we can determine the background redshift, we can further distinguish whether the candidates are true lenses or just spiral/diffuse galaxies because the background redshift should be larger than the foreground spec-z or photo-z. In contrast, spiral or diffuse galaxies have similar foreground and background redshifts. On the other hand, for âˆ¼15similar-toabsent15\sim 15âˆ¼ 15 systems (i.e., âˆ¼30%similar-toabsentpercent30\sim 30\%âˆ¼ 30 % of the full catalog), the photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z of the source is similar if not smaller than the spec-zğ‘§zitalic_z of the deflector, suggesting that these photo-zğ‘§zitalic_z are likely to be wrong.
